climbs.name: Tres Viejos
climbs.fa: M. Rangel, M. Trainor, S. Tweito

content.description: At the tallest part of cliff a lone large boulder sits atop the second pitch. Pitch 1 starts on the right facing dihedral capped by a roof (go right); gear belay (5.8, 100'). Pitch 2 gain the small roof and make tricky moves to get above this, take the cracks straight up to another slight overhang and finish below the big boulder (5.10+, 100'). Pitch 3 wanders straight back to the wall to an obvious broken dihedral (5.9, 100'); go left 10' near top to large pine with sling.
content.protection:
Double rack to #2, single 3,4 camalot; nuts; few slings and 10 quick draws. 

  First pitch has bolted anchor; second pitch has rope at base of boulder; third is a slung Pine tree.
content.location: At bottom of central gorge is a nice large flat spot to hang out. Look for the large boulder atop the second pitch to orient yourself. The first pitch is a very obvious dihedral, some lichen makes it look less than great but it's fine.

content.description: The first pitch is shared by Tres Viejos. This route heads straight up at the end of the first pitch until a horizontal crack can bypass the overhang. Traversing along the second pitch on trees seemed like the crux. I'd like to finish the route straight up but it needs bolts.
content.protection: Double rack cams to #3, nuts, slings and quickdraws
content.location: Start is a right facing dihedral on the north-facing wall. Rappel the route with single 60m rope.

content.description:
Shady north-facing wall about 300' tall, usually windy in the canyon floor. Water continuously serenades one. 

  Lonely place with only two known routes. Bolts scattered about suggest some other explorers but no other routes seem completed.
